results.title: Home alone. Home alone 2 = Lost in New York
results.creator_credit: Chris Colombus, John Hughes and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Home alone is one of the most successful comedies of the eighties and stars pint-sized hero Macaulay Culkin. In a chaotic frenzy to get to the airport on time, the McCallister family forget one thing - eight year old Kevin. When two bungling burglars attempt to break into the McCallister household, Kevin is left home alone to defend himself and his house. He outwits the burglars by waging war the only way he knows how, with outlandish, yet effective boyhood pranks. Cast includes Joe Pesci, Daniel Stern, John Heard and John Candy. In the sequel to “Home alone” it’s Kevin who manages to isolate himself from the rest of the family when he boards the wrong plane at Christmastime and finds himself in New York city. He’s not alone for long however, as he quickly befriends a pigeon-lady and, once again crosses paths with two well known dim witted criminals. Cast includes Joe Pesci, Daniel Stern and Brenda Fricker.

results.title: Holzwege: wood roads/wrong ways
results.creator_credit: George Wallace-Crabbe and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Inspired by the diaries of a prisoner (in this case Nazi war criminal Albert Speer). In his daily exercise Speer began to measure the kilometres covered and projected his walk, in imaginative terms, across Southern Europe to Asia, Russia and the frozen Bering Strait. The film is constructed like a documentary of his imaginary journey. Holzwege, which translates as ‘wood road’ or ‘wrong way’ or ‘dead end’, was the pseudonym he used when signing the diaries.

results.title: Holy rollers
results.creator_credit: Rosie Jones, Sharyn Prentice, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Flamingo Star Films
results.brief_description: Suzi Rosedale is an Australian woman living in an outer suburb of Jerusalem, offering guided tours of the city and surrounding areas for visitors on religious pilgrimages. This Australian made documentary follows Suzi on various trips as she takes groups of Mormons, Catholics, Jews and Muslims to the sites of Jesus’ life, literally following in his footsteps. The exact location where key events occurred are contested by various guides who offer differing opinions as to “the” place where, for example, Jesus was buried. Suzi calmly takes all things in her stride including a client in need of an unavailable can of Sprite with his dinner in a kibbutz. The need for the tourism industry to make money from such endeavours is matched by the emotional effect that the Holy Land has on its visitors. Technology meets ancient religious beliefs as Suzi escorts the tour around in an air-conditioned bus and each client is hooked up with a headset in order to hear Suzi’s commentary when on site. The commercial side of religious tours is exposed but not ridiculed in this entertaining documentary. Phillip Adams provides a comprehensive voice-over throughout. Filmed on video.

results.title: Holocaust
results.creator_credit: Ben Kerner, Daivid Shitz, Yigal Efrati and Israel Film Service
results.brief_description: This documentary traces the history of Nazism from its earliest roots in 1918 and focuses on the antisemetic nature of its doctrines. The rich cultural, religious and social world of Eastern Europe with its large numbers of Jewish people were destroyed by the evil flames of the Holocaust. The horror of the concentration camps, the bravery of the resistance fighters of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising and the Jewish partisans who desperately tried to save their people is documented in this moving analysis of what remains one of the greatest crimes in human history: the deliberate and systematic attempt to exterminate human beings on the grounds of race, colour and religion.

results.title: Hollywood: the fabulous era
results.brief_description: This documentary hosted and narrated by Henry Fonda, is an examination of Hollywood from the era of sound to the 1950s. In 1927 talkies were introduced for the first time - an event that revolutionised the motion picture industry. The rise in popularity of action and gangster films in the 1930s made stars of anti-heroes such as James Cagney and Edward G. Robinson, when the most popular themes of the era were sex and violence. Also examined are the ways in which Hollywood films responded to the Depression of the 1930s, the war years and the prosperity of the late 1940s. Movie stars dazzled the burgeoning film going public with premiers, selling the dream (both on and off the screen) to audiences. In the 1950s television posed a major threat to box office receipts, which resulted in the introduction of new cinema technology and new genres to lure audiences back to the theatre. Featuring numerous clips from classics of the 1930s, 40s and 50s and music by Elmer Bernstein.

results.title: Hollywood: song & dance
results.creator_credit: Ray Selfe, Derek Blades and EPA
results.brief_description: Narrated by Bob Sessions this is the story of the development of song and dance in the Hollywood film. Concentrating on the performances of the thirties and forties it explores how song and dance routines became more sophisticated with advancements in technology. Most of the emphasis is on the extensive range of clips selected from the films of those decades, featuring such greats as Al Jolson and including early performances by Bing Crosby, Bob Hope, Peggy Lee…. Other more surprising performances include Laurel and Hardy, James Cagney and John Wayne! Legendary actresses such as Betty Grable and Yvonne De Carlo show the range of their skills, and Barbara Stanwyck’s early singing debut is recorded - in a costume that caused censorship problems in more than one country. The peerless Fred Astaire delights in an energetic orchestral number epitomising the golden era of song and dance. “Song and Dance” is a deserving tribute to some great performers.

results.title: Hollywood without makeup
results.brief_description: Actor and Producer Ken Murray’s fascination with capturing candid moments in the lives of Hollywood stars came about as a result of purchasing a home movie-camera to record his own early stage performances. This extraordinary compilation of footage, narrated by Murray, captures the essence of Hollywood from its early days, to the rise of the star system and the domination of the big studios. Murray refers to his work as a “day by day personal film diary”, created to document memories of those who worked and played hard in the film industry. Highlights of this compilation include a publicity stunt involving Groucho and Harpo Marx, Jackie Cooper and Charles Laughton racing midget-cars down a street on the Paramount Studio lot; the on and off-set antics of Cary Grant during the filming of Gunga Din at Lone Pine; the television debuts of Kirk Douglas and Marilyn Monroe; footage shot inside Randolph Heart’s imposing ranch, San Simeon; and a cross-country train trip to publicise the film Virginia City, with the film’s leading man Errol Flynn and other stars, such as Humphrey Bogart, aboard. Also features footage of Charlie Chaplin, Clarke Gable, John Gilbert, Fred MacMurray, Jerome Power, Linda Darnell, Norma Shearer, Mae West, Laurel and Hardy, Cecil. B. Demille, Johnny Weissmuller, Douglas Fairbanks, Mary Pickford, Louella Parsons, Dick Powell, Carole Lombard, George Raft, Clara Bowe, Tom Mix, Mary Astor, Jane Wyman, Lucille Ball, Donna Reed, John Wayne, Robert Taylor, and Walt Disney.

results.title: Hollywood the early years: Hollywood song and dance
results.creator_credit: Derek Blades, Ray Selfe, EPA and Wonderland Entertainment
results.brief_description: This documentary tracks the history of the representation of song and dance in Hollywood films in the 1920s and 1930s. The transition from silent movies to sound facilitated new challenges for those attempting to present musical routines on the silver screen. This documentary shows archival footage from the 1920s when show numbers were filmed on a stage and the soundtrack was heard by the audience via a large record playing. In the 1930s the popularity of musicals were on the wane when musical director Busby Berkeley revived the genre with innovative ways to film musical numbers. Extensive footage of Bing Crosby, Bob Hope, Shirley Temple, Betty Grable, James Cagney, Roy Rogers, John Wayne and Barbara Stanwyck displays the evolution of the way that musical routines were presented to audiences. Special honours are reserved for Fred Astaire, who with his innovative and legendary routines had a great understanding of the relationship of dance to the film medium. Narrated by Bob Sessions.
